captions.text: Sup playas? I hope you like R Kelly - cuz this week we mackin jailbait with Lolita by Vladimir Nabokov.

Humbert Humbert ain’t yo average horndog.
This fool only got eyes

for a special little girls age 9 to fu**in 14, or
“nymphets” as he like to call em’.

See, back when he was a young’un,
Humbert had a lil sweet thang with a girl

named Annabel. But since she up and died before
he was able to get some, he spendin the rest

of his days lookin for a girl who gonna remind
of his first hunny love.

Well lucky for Humbert, he rents a
room in the house of Charlotte Haze, who got

herself a 12 year old daughter named Dolores-
but Humbert call this tease Lolita. And he

gettn all riled up just thinkin bout this
baby dip.

Unfortunately Lolita ain’t the one
tryna freak wit him. Charlotte’s old ass

be all up on his nuts like nobody’s bidness.
And when Humbert can’t duck her no mo, he

decide to marry her so he can stay close to
Lolita.

S’all good til one day Charlotte goes sniffin
around in Humbert’s

diary. After learning that he can’t stand
her stank ass but loves little Lolita, Charlotte

gets all crunk and storms outta the house
when BAM- girl gets TOOKEN OUT by a car. She
dead.

So Humbert scoops up Lolita, brings
her to a motel and finds out that this little
girl knows more about freakin than he thought.
Man that's nasty y'all

So they hit the road swangin from
spot to spot all round the country. All the

while, Humbert think there be some scrub creepin
on em.

Eventually Humbert park it in some
hood and sends lil Lolita to school. But when

Lolita start talkin wit otha boys and actin
all shady, Humbert won’t stop baggin on

her. Outta nowhere, Lolita say they should
peace outta town.

On the road, Lolita gets ill and
Humbert drops her at the hospital. But when

he return, da nurse tell him “her uncle”
already got her. Whaaat? She ain’t got no
uncle!

Humbert all torn up bout losing
Lolita and spends YEARS lookin for her. One

day, he gets a letter from Lolita saying that
she married, knocked up, and need some cash.

So Humbert drops everything and slides over
to where she at.

Lolita tells him that the fool who
took her from the hospital was some playwright

named Clare Quilty, and he was the one who
creepin on them since back when. But that
fool long gone now.

Humbert begs her to drop her hubby
and come back to him. But after she shuts

his ass down, he throws her some dough, finds
Quilty, and fills his bitch ass with some
hot ones.

So Humbert gets thrown in a psych ward, and
then the slammer, where
he writes his memoir.

First thing you best recognize is
that we dealin with the king of unreliable

narrators up in this text. Not only is Humby
all whacked out in the head, but that fool
straight up lies to us.

Real talk or no, this thug’s memoir
spillin clean over with literary references
and fancy talk.

That’s part of what makes this book so damn
cray. When homies peep game at Humbert’s

fly-ass prose and dank
jokes, they don’t find the monster they

expectin. Instead, they find a funny, book-smart
hood who got his own problems- and a bitch

IS one. Eventually, the reader ends up sympathizing
with this crazy mofo.

But that ain’t all Humbert doin by
showcasin his verbal skillz. By spittin all

dat fancy descriptive jive bout the world
around him, Humbert messes with the readers

head and makes them think bout regular erryday
sh** in a new way.

So when you reading this and start
questioning “what’s normal?” Then Humbert

dun got you by the balls sucka. Cuz when all
dem pretty words pull you in to his reality,

his whack-ass passions ain’t so whack no
mo.

So not only does this book got a narrator
who ain’t reliable, but this fool gone and

even made the
reader unreliable. Damn! Ain’t that some

Peep game at this mythological
reference, home boy. In Greek Myth, Nymphs

are often chased by hustlas who can’t keep
it in their pants. Take Daphne and Apollo,

for instance. When Daphne was duckin Apollo’s
grubby paws, the only way she could escape
is by transforming in to a Laurel Tree.

Turns out, it ain’t no different
for nymphets neither.

By the end, Lolita ain’t Lo. Ain’t Lola. Ain’t
Dolores. She now Dolly Schiller. And she’s
finally free.

Thanks for ballin with me today.
Don’t forget to subscribe and, as always,
keep it real. Peace.

comments.text:
Great analysis, but with one key element missing: Lo dies. In the forward 
to the book by the fictional executor of Humbert's will or something, he 
mentions off the cuff that Lo died in child birth and Humbert died of some 
sort of liver failure in prison. Humbert destroyed her life. She is free, 
but she cannot enjoy that freedom.﻿

comments.author: joey castle

comments.text:
What I loved about this book was that I found myself empathizing with the 
narrator so much, I was actually cheering for him to get what he wanted 
(Lolita). Of course, this led to some very weird inner struggles in my 
head, because I know she's only 12 and I had to keep reminding myself of 
that. I'm no pedo, but this book had me rethinking everything I know as 
right or wrong. The subjects in this book may be hard for some to grasp, 
but the book isn't just about having sex with 12-year-olds, it's about 
entering Humbert's psyche and losing yourself in it and thus understanding 
his madness. ﻿
comments.author: DaBagelSquad

comments.text:
Also, because Lolita's character is so romanticized by Humbert, it also 
made me wonder who she really was. To be honest, I don't think she was this 
sex tigress who chased after older men like he wants us to believe. I think 
the older men took advantage of her and she became "broken" by it. Her eyes 
are described as "grey" in the book, which can indicate her indifference to 
anything that's happening around her- no matter how fucked up it seems to 
be. In the book, she doesn't really show too much sadness after finding out 
her mother was dead. Either Humbert didn't want to admit to us that Lolita 
was that heartbroken, or he refused to believe she felt anything except her 
lust for him.
comments.author: DaBagelSquad

Awesome overview! Actually got me hooked and had to know the ending from 
this summary. Only thing that bothered me is that, while the protagonist 
got more or less what he deserved, Lolita herself got to live a free life. 
Abusing his love to squeeze him out of money, leaving and cheating on him 
then calling him back for more money? Should have ended up dead, either by 
the hands of the protagonist, her lover, or just an accident to complete 
the circle.﻿

comments.author: KJKING326

comments.text:
Accurate analysis but i  read the book a few months ago and i think you 
didn't mention something about the main character. He was constantly 
pursuing Lolita and devoting his time and money to make her happy. But the 
fabulous gifts and fancy dinners didn't change the way the girl treated 
him. Yeah i mean they did do some nasty things together, but that was 
superficial. She was never romanticaly attached towards him the way he was 
driven to her. It really is a story about unshared love. Even though 
Humbert wasn't exactly the most decent man, he really cherished this girl 
and wanted her well-being. His love for her was so destructive that 
breaking the law (both constitutional and moral) didnt pose a threat to 
him. On the other hand i think that Lolitta was quite sinister. She 
probably knew what was going in his heart and mind and promptly took 
advantage of that. She basically pushed him into buying her all kinds of 
stuff and she knew that he would not refuse because he was afraid that she 
might get offended  and  run away from him. So i find one more theme here. 
And that is that some girls use their irresistible looks to trick guys into 
spending money on them. Some guys treat women like royals.
But as we witness these girls don't love these man back.  They just keep 
the relationship going with the purpose of fulfiling their needs and once 
that is over they loose interest.
 Sorry if i made mistakes (This is not my native language) but i wanted to 
share my thoughts on the book. I'm a 20 year old student from Europe and 
would like to spark a discusion where we can exchange opinions about 
classic novels. Keep on the Good work :)﻿
comments.author: Христо Смоленов

comments.text:
I see how you could think that, the author is building sympathy for Humbert 
through out the book. I disagree. Humbert pursues her and protects her out 
of selfish lust. He keeps her on the road and constantly moving, prevents 
her from forming bonds with anyone other than himself lies to her 
constantly. Her only method of gaing any measure of sef determination is 
play along and collect enough money to make a run for it. Part of the 
artistry of the writer is make Humbert seem sympathetic, but take away the 
beautiful romantic prose and he his a delusional, pedophile, who kidnapped 
and repeatedly raped his step daughter then tr7ed to assuage her with money 
and gifts.

I saw her as the devil when I read it. If you watch the 1997 movie, it 
reinforces the idea that she took advantage of this seemingly sick man. 
There's even a scene where they're having sex and she stops him in the 
middle and makes him pay her. She stashes all the money she feels she's 
earned to escape him later on. So, maybe this is a broken, twisted girl who 
meets a sick, gullible man and she takes advantage of him more than he 
takes advantage of her (both in the movie and in the book).

comments.author: burtburtist

comments.text:
+mralanv This definitely wasn't a sugar daddy situation. Sugar babies are 
willing to give sex for things. She actually seems ambivalent about the 
sex. She is repulsed by this father-figure wanting her, but drawn towards 
sex (in a general sense) because she's a teenager. She doesn't have sex 
with him for money; she needs Humbert. She has absolutely no one else. 
She's a child whose father is long-dead, whose dead mother absolutely 
loathed her, has no experience of the world, no way to earn money, and is 
in Humbert's charge. She is totally at his mercy. He loved her in a sick 
way, and Lolita may have initially been infatuated with this older, worldly 
man, but she wants nothing to do with him sexually, and despises him by the 
end. She tries to hide from him in order to avoid having sex with him at 
times. If it had been about money, she would have gone with him in the end 
when he says he'll take her "swollen with another man's child," instead of 
living in abject poverty. This is a cleverly, brilliantly crafted tale by a 
man wanting to sway an audience (the "jurors" he mentions often) in his 
favor. He desperately wants his story to be a tragic love-story where he 
ends up the victim. He wants us to believe it, and he wants to believe it 
himself. If he were to break it down into its parts, the story looks pretty 
abominable: he marries a woman because he wants to have sex with her child; 
after Mother dies, he's ecstatic because he can do the darkest of deeds 
with his now-daughter without any interruptions; he rapes her again and 
again until she finally finds a way out; he hunts her down and tries to 
reclaim her; finally, he murders his daughter's lover, not because he finds 
Quilty's actions deplorable, but because he sees Quilty as competition. 
Nabokov's ability to make us "feel" for Humbert is the true genius of this 
novel. Sorry for rambling on so... :(
comments.author: SmittenKitten

comments.text:
I didn't read the book, and you're right, there ARE these relationships 
where women can swallow their dignity and give their bodies over to a man 
in order to get objects, and it works best with desperate guys like the 
narrator here. But having said that, wanting the well-being of your 
girlfriend or the well being of a teenage girl does NOT make someone a 
decent person. Just because he is desperate for sex, and is willing to 
spend a lot of money on it, doesn't mean he was a good person.

comments.author: joana carvalho

comments.text:
He was her sugar daddy, but I don't think he loved her either, it was pure 
physical attraction. I read this book two years ago -- I'll probably read 
it again once I'm done with the LOTR --, so I'm not sure if my facts about 
this book are entirely correct. I remember reading an excerpt from this 
novel in which he pondered on what he would do once her looks started to 
fade away, he'd just dump her for another Lolita. In another chapter, he 
imagines having a daughter with Dolores: a second Lolita by his side. They 
traveled together for a couple of years, within that time frame, he noticed 
that she was growing up fast, therefore, she wouldn't be a nymphet forever. 
He was already scheming ways to get her replaced by another girl. He'd 
probably abuse his daughter if he'd had one, Humbert was a sick man. I 
agree that their relationship was symbiotic. They leeched off each other. 
She was aware that he only wanted her for sex, and she used that to make 
him splash out his money on her , she prostitued herself. She escapes from 
him, and shacks up with the other paedophile; but, apparently, she had 
feelings for that old guy! that's what I didn't get. Why would she leave 
Humbert to fall straight into another old guy's turf?

comments.author: jgerardo231208

comments.text:
Beautifully poetic novel by Nabokov.  Funny as shit analysis compliments 
of Thug Notes.   
I remember the first time I read "Lolita".  The year, I believe, was 1994.  
I remember sitting in Big Blue, my beloved recliner.  As my eyes danced 
over the pages and the rain outside played its enchanting music, I fell 
into some sort of magical trance, transported by some of the most exquisite 
prose I'd ever encountered.  While subsequent readings may have lacked the 
same ethereal quality, I'm sure that each and every one of them was special 
in its own way.
 
Yes, this work of art is forbidden to moralistic dolts.  They may turn its 
pages, but they lack the intelligence and sensibility to appreciate and 
enjoy it--though I'm sure if they tried they would at least find in 
Charlotte Haze (Lo's mother) an eternal soul mate.﻿
